summary:
Here is a clear and concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Reaffirms previous resolutions on Haiti and commends Haitian authorities and the Haitian National Police (HNP) for ensuring credible and inclusive elections.

Commends the Special Representative of the Secretary-General and the United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti (MINUSTAH) for their efforts in supporting the political process and maintaining a secure environment.

Expresses appreciation to MINUSTAH personnel and Member States that contributed to the mission.

Welcomes the strengthening and professionalization of the HNP, but notes the need for continued international support.

Emphasizes the importance of continued UN and international community support for Haiti's long-term security and development.

Reaffirms the primary responsibility of the Haitian Government in implementing peacebuilding and sustaining peace strategies.

Acknowledges progress made, but notes significant humanitarian challenges, particularly after Hurricane Matthew.

Welcomes the General Assembly's resolution on the UN's 'New Approach to Cholera in Haiti'.

Recognizes the importance of strengthening national human rights institutions and respect for human rights.

Considers developing a broader framework of mutual accountability among the Government of Haiti, the UN, and the international community.

Welcomes the Secretary-General's report and recommends establishing a new UN peacekeeping mission in Haiti to consolidate gains and strengthen national capacity.

Acts under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations to establish the new mission.
1. Decides to extend MINUSTAH's mandate for a final six-month period, until 15 October 2017, and close the Mission by that date.

2. The military component of MINUSTAH will gradually draw down and fully withdraw from Haiti by 15 October 2017.

3. Reaffirms the importance of strengthening the justice sector and the Haitian National Police (HNP) for the Government of Haiti to take responsibility for security needs.

4. Requests the Secretary-General to reduce MINUSTAH tasks and prioritize a successful transition to MINUJUSTH.

5. Establishes MINUJUSTH, a follow-on peacekeeping mission, for an initial six-month period from 16 October 2017 to 15 April 2018, with up to seven Formed Police Units (FPUs) and 295 Individual Police Officers (IPOs).

6. MINUJUSTH will assist the Government of Haiti to strengthen rule of law institutions, support and develop the HNP, and engage in human rights monitoring.

7. MINUJUSTH will be headed by a Special Representative of the Secretary-General with a good offices and advocacy role.

8. MINUJUSTH will retain seven FPUs, deployed to five regional departments, to provide operational support to the HNP.

9. The 295 IPOs will play a key role in implementing the HNP Strategic Development Plan 2017-2021.

10. The 38 government-provided corrections personnel will support efforts to strengthen the Directorate of Prisons Administration (DAP) management.

11. MINUJUSTH's rule of law efforts will be part of a strategy towards a continued, progressive transition to development actors.

12. Authorizes MINUJUSTH to use necessary means to carry out its mandate to support and develop the HNP.

13. Authorizes MINUJUSTH to protect civilians under imminent threat of physical violence.

14. Requests the Secretary-General to ensure medical enablers and air assets necessary to deploy security forces.

15. Reaffirms the importance of gender mainstreaming throughout MINUJUSTH's mandate.

16. Recognizes the ownership and primary responsibility of the Government and people of Haiti over the country's development.

17. Recalls resolution 2272 (2016) and requests the Secretary-General to ensure full compliance with the United Nations zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse.

18. Commends troop- and police-contributing countries and highlights the importance of addressing issues that may affect mandate implementation.

19. Affirms the importance of a successful and responsible transition between MINUSTAH and MINUJUSTH.

20. Requests the Secretary-General to establish a MINUJUSTH advance planning team and complete the joint MINUSTAH and UNCT Transition Plan.

21. Requests the Secretary-General to report to the Security Council on the implementation of this resolution within 90 days and 180 days.

22. Requests the initial 90-day report to include details on the joint MINUSTAH and UNCT Transition Plan.
The Security Council:

23. Expresses its intent to continue reviewing conditions in Haiti and consider adapting MINUJUSTH's mandate and police force levels as needed to preserve progress towards durable security and stability;

24. Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
